title: The Bridge of Forgiveness
devotional:
Imagine a weathered wooden bridge spanning a deep ravine. Years of storms and countless footsteps have left their mark. Now, envision someone deliberately hacking at its supports with an axe. That's what unforgiveness does to our hearts. It weakens our foundation, leaving us vulnerable to collapse under the weight of pain and resentment.

Forgiveness isn't about condoning the wrong done to us. It's not about minimizing the hurt or pretending it didn't happen. True forgiveness is a deliberate act of releasing the offender from the debt they owe us. It's a conscious choice to let go of bitterness and anger, even when those feelings seem justified. It’s like choosing to repair the weakened supports of that bridge, reinforcing it against future storms.

Think of Joseph in the Old Testament. He was betrayed by his brothers, sold into slavery, and unjustly imprisoned. Years later, he rose to power in Egypt, and his brothers, desperate for food during a famine, came to him for help. Joseph had every right to seek revenge. He could have easily destroyed them. Yet, he chose forgiveness. He recognized God's hand in his suffering and understood that even the most grievous wrongs could be used for good. In Genesis 50:20, Joseph tells his brothers, "You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives."

Forgiving someone, especially when the hurt is deep, is not easy. It requires humility, vulnerability, and a willingness to surrender our right to hold onto anger. It requires relying on God's strength and grace to do what we cannot do on our own. It's a journey, not a destination. Some days, the pain may resurface, and the temptation to harbor resentment may feel overwhelming. But even then, we can choose to reaffirm our commitment to forgiveness, trusting that God will heal our wounds and restore our hearts.

Choosing forgiveness is like setting a prisoner free and discovering that the prisoner was you. It releases us from the chains of bitterness and allows us to move forward with peace and joy. It allows God to work in our lives and in the lives of those who have wronged us. Forgiveness is not just a gift we give to others; it's a gift we give to ourselves.
image_description: A weathered wooden bridge spanning a rocky ravine, with sunlight illuminating part of the bridge.
insights: The act of forgiveness is central to the Christian faith. Jesus' teachings emphasize the importance of forgiving others, as reflected in the Lord's Prayer (Matthew 6:12, 14-15): 'And forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors... For if you forgive other people when they sin against you, your heavenly Father will also forgive you. But if you do not forgive others their sins, your Father will not forgive your sins.' This highlights the reciprocal nature of forgiveness and its connection to our relationship with God.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle to forgive those who have hurt me. The pain feels so real, and the anger seems justified. Help me to release my bitterness and resentment. Give me the strength to forgive as You have forgiven me. Heal my wounded heart and fill me with Your peace. Help me to see the offender through Your eyes and to trust that You can work even the most difficult situations for good. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Who is someone you need to forgive today? What is holding you back from forgiving them? What steps can you take to begin the process of forgiveness, trusting that God will guide you and strengthen you along the way?
